docs.lead_paragraph: Sometime around last Thanksgiving, Gov. George E. Pataki and Dennis Rivera, a union leader, had a private conversation about money. Neither man will talk about what was said. But the governor needed to close a budget gap and Mr. Rivera needed a vast sum to pay for raises under a new contract with New York City's hospitals.

headline.main: Before Bills Move in Albany, 3 Leaders Cut Deals in

docs.abstract: Second of three articles about legislative atrophy in Albany describes process of cutting deals in secret (The Albany Syndrome); cites as case study passage of Health Care Workforce Recruitment and Retention Act of 2002, bill that was passed before many lawmakers had read it, after Gov George E Pataki provided 'message of necessity' to skirt constitutional requirement that bills sit at last three days in each house before vote; bill was crafted in meetings between Pataki and Dennis Rivera, union leader, followed by seven weeks of secret work; it calls for bevy of new revenues, supplying cash for Rivera's workers and also to pay for costly existing state programs; there were no public hearings held, and Insurance and Health Committees in each house never saw bill or voted on it; critics say such secret negotiations followed by lightning-quick action produce shoddy legislation and help to mask bill's unattractive ramifications; detailed look at passage of bill; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Forgotten Domestic Crisis,'' by Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, Oct. 13): The time has come for a comprehensive universal system of health care run jointly by the federal government and the private sector, with room for minor adjustment by individual states.

docs.lead_paragraph: I.The Disappearing Middle When I was a teenager growing up on Long Island, one of my favorite excursions was a trip to see the great Gilded Age mansions of the North Shore. Those mansions weren't just pieces of architectural history. They were monuments to a bygone social era, one in which the rich could afford the armies of servants needed to maintain a house the size of a European palace. By the time I saw them, of course, that era was long past. Almost none of the Long Island mansions were still private residences. Those that hadn't been turned into museums were occupied by nursing homes or private schools. For the America I grew up in -- the America of the 1950's and 1960's -- was a middle-class society, both in reality and in feel. The vast income and wealth inequalities of the Gilded Age had disappeared. Yes, of course, there was the poverty of the underclass -- but the conventional wisdom of the time viewed that as a social rather than an economic problem. Yes, of course, some wealthy businessmen and heirs to large fortunes lived far better than the average American. But they weren't rich the way the robber barons who built the mansions had been rich, and there weren't that many of them. The days when plutocrats were a force to be reckoned with in American society, economically or politically, seemed long past.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman article outlines how permissive capitalism of economic boom has destroyed American equality; says there have been tectonic shifts in distribution of income and wealth in America, and middle-class America of his youth is gone; fears that few people are aware of just how much gap between very rich and rest has widened over relatively short period of time; says 13,000 richest families in America now have almost as much income as 20 million poorest; says bringing up subject exposes person to charges of 'class warfare' and finds few people willing to talk about profound effects--economic, social and political--of that widening gap; says concentration of income at top is key reason that United States, for all its economic achievements, has more poverty and lower life expectancy than any other major advanced nation; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN people buy health insurance, few worry that it might run out. As long as they pay their premiums, they expect to be covered, no matter how many medical bills they rack up. After all, what's the point of having insurance if, just when you need it most, your policy shuts down like a bank at closing time? Many policies, however, do place a cap on the amount they will pay out over the course of a person's lifetime. More than two-thirds of people in preferred-provider organizations have such lifetime benefit maximums, as do nearly half of people covered by conventional indemnity plans, according to a recent survey of employer health benefits by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Lifetime caps are less common among plans offered by health maintenance organizations.
docs.abstract: More than two-thirds of people in preferred provider health insurance plans and nearly half of those covered by conventional indemnity plans hold policies that place cap on amount they will pay out over course of person's lifetime; severe illness or injury easily exceeds many plans' lifetime caps, leaving insured persons without coverage; lifetime caps are less common among plans offered by health maintenance organizations; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE most top executives, Frank Baldino Jr. sometimes does not get enough sleep. But Dr. Baldino, the founder and chief executive of Cephalon Inc., a biotechnology company, may be able to cope with lack of sleep better than most. He has a prescription for Provigil, his company's No. 1 drug, which some doctors and users say has the ability to keep people awake and alert for hours, or even days. And it appears to do so without the side effects -- the buzz and jitteriness, or the risk of addiction -- of coffee or amphetamines.
docs.abstract: Use of Provigil, Cephalon drug approved in 1998 to treat sleepiness associated with narcolepsy, is expanding rapidly, with more than 80 percent of prescriptions written to treat fatigue and sleepiness associated with many other diseases or just plain sleepiness; growing sales redeem reputation of Frank Baldino Jr, chief executive, which took beating after FDA rejected Cephalon's treatment for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; also raise questions about company's promotion of Provigil and about society's use of it as so-called lifestyle drug; photos; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: TODAY'S apothecary is most often a supermarket or chain-store pharmacy, where pills that can do everything from relieving an upset stomach to reducing allergy symptoms are sold as part a billion-dollar drug industry led by global pharmaceutical companies. But modern medicine can also be dispensed by pharmacists who, instead of using pills supplied by companies, go back to the basics.
docs.abstract: Article on Michael Roberge and David Gaudio, Connecticut pharmacists who custom-make and sell compound medicines; Roberge, owner of Compounded Solutions in Monroe, fills about 125 prescriptions weekly while Gaudio and staff at Prescription Specialties in Cheshire handle 90 to 100 prescriptions a day; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Health Plans Are Offering Fewer Choices and Higher Costs'' (Oct. 6) described the choices facing employees of large companies during this open enrollment season for health insurance plans. But the situation is far bleaker for small businesses and their employees. Today, access to health care is unsustainable for many working families. As health care costs skyrocket for many reasons that the market can't control, only government can provide universal access and reasonably control costs.
docs.abstract: Dr Jerry Frankel letter comments on Oct 6 article about fewer choices and greater costs of health insurance plans currently being offered to employees

docs.lead_paragraph: HOPING to tempt a panel of venture capitalists and lure new investment, participants in the first annual Westchester Mayors' Business Summit on Wednesday promoted their cities' recent economic achievements. More than 200 business and government leaders attended. Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers detailed recent developments along his city's waterfront. He began with the $53 million Larkin Center, the new home of the Yonkers Public Library and the city's Board of Education, which opened in September.

headline.main: Mayors Tout Cities' Health to Tempt Investors

docs.abstract: More than 200 business and government leaders attend first annual Westchester Mayors' Business Summit, whose aim is to persuade venture capitalists to invest in development and redevelopment projects (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, Oct. 13) recommends a single-payer system similar to those in Britain and Canada. This prefers a nationalized managed care collective over the dominant H.M.O.-managed care collectives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki listened closely yesterday as he stood on the deck of the pilot boat New York with Brian Monahan, the Democratic mayor of Dobbs Ferry. Mr. Monahan pointed out a privately owned stretch of riverbank that he would love to annex to a waterfront park. ''I'm looking for a governor who can help me,'' he said.

headline.main: Pataki Gets the Endorsement Of 10 Hudson River Mayors

docs.abstract: New York Gov George Pataki is endorsed for re-election by ten mayors of towns along Hudson River; group cruises river and views revitalization and cleanup projects supported by Pataki; photo; Democratic challenger Carl McCall, in Manhattan, denounces Pataki on medical insurance and other issues (M)
